assessmentItem.title: Find the LCM of two numbers

itemBody.div: Find the Lowest Common Multiple (LCM) of and

div.feedbackInline: You have entered the GCD of and , but the question asks for the LCM (lowest common multiple).

feedbackBlock.p: You have had three attempts at answering this question, so here is the solution:
We find the prime factors of the numbers:
The Greatest Common Divisor has all the factors that occur in both and :
Since there are no factors which occur in both numbers, the GCD is 1.
The Lowest Common Multiple must be divisible by both and .
So we need all the factors that are in and all the factors that are in .
Since the GCD is 1, there are no factors shared by and .
So we can find the LCM by multiplying by .
Hence the LCM of and is
The Lowest Common Multiple must be divisible by both and .
So we need all the factors that are in and all the factors that are in .
In this case, though, divides , so the LCM is .
The Lowest Common Multiple must be divisible by both and .
So we need all the factors that are in and all the factors that are in .
The factors that are in the GCD are in both and , so if we multiply by those factors are repeated.
So we can find the LCM by either multiplying by and dividing by the GCD
or by multiplying by the factors of which are not in the GCD.
Either way, the LCM of and is
Since you have viewed the solution, your score for this question will be 0.
Since you have viewed the hint, your score for this question will be halved.
